title: International students sue over Trump admin revoking visas
author: Rachel Wolf

facts.content: International students whose visas have been revoked are suing the Trump administration over an alleged violation of due process.
The Associated Press reported that the students are arguing that the Trump administration lacked justification when canceling visas.
Several international students have had their visas revoked for reasons related to their activism, including pro-Palestinian activism being argued as support for Hamas.
Some international students reportedly had their visas revoked for past infractions such as traffic violations.
Students in at least 30 states have had their visas revoked.
The government is using a foreign policy statute from 1952 to justify the visa cancellations.
A judge ruled that Mahmoud Khalil, a Columbia University student, could be deported, stating that the government met the burden of proof.
The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) provided reasons for Khalil's visa revocation, including not being forthcoming about his involvement with certain organizations.
International students looking to study in the U.S. must meet specific requirements to obtain the appropriate visa.

The DHS lists several circumstances under which the government may revoke a student visa, including absence from the U.S. for five months or longer, expulsion, unauthorized employment, and failure to enroll.
International students may maintain their legal residency status and continue their studies even after having their visas revoked.
Losing legal residency status ultimately puts students at risk of being deported.
Trump administration officials have defended the revocation of student visas.
Secretary of State Marco Rubio stated that the government can cancel a student visa under the law.

judgements.content: Several international students have been caught in the crosshairs as the administration argues their pro-Palestinian activism constitutes support for Hamas.
The characterization of the visa revocations as a 'crackdown on immigration' implies a negative evaluation of the Trump administration's immigration policies.

quotes.content: There is no right to a student visa. We can cancel a student visa under the law just the same way that we can deny a student visa under the law. And we will do so in cases we find appropriate.
